docs.title: Home
docs.text:
# Steal These Ideas

Steal These Ideas is a free library of plug-and-play D&D material: prebuilt high-quality characters with clear personality, narrative hooks and unique voice. Remix what you want, ignore the rest.

All characters created in the official character creator tool at DNDBeyond.com, with minimal homebrew clearly marked.

About me: Experienced writer of prose and fiction, gamemaster in various RPG systems for almost 30 years. This project has been a creative outlet through a period of illness, and I'd like to share it freely with the D&D community.

Note: Visual aid and graphics are AI generated, with love and care on a zero-budget. If this is an issue, feel free to ignore any images and focus on the actual content.

Updated: 2026-01-25 • v0.2 · CHANGELOG

docs.title: Why this helps you run better games
docs.text:
• Save prep time: highly individual drop-in NPCs and PCs ready for adventure.
  • Session-ready: stat blocks, hooks, and sample dialogue crafted by an experienced writer.
  • Remix-friendly: free to use and share with attribution, non-commercial. 🔖 License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0. See the full terms in the README.

docs.title: Explore
docs.text:
Alveta “Velvet” Air Genasi Glory Paladin. Her childhood stickfights became a scam dojo, now she fights to vindicate her dream. Basil Tenebrian Noble Bladesinger Shifter, hunted by his brother, but still a Good Boy. Struggles with body dysmorphia and clings to decency like a drowning man. Beitian “Betty” Winter’s Heart A Soulknife gambler from a rare, all-deaf clan who clings desperately to her self-image as Dragonchess prodigy, and lives for gossip and mustard. Belvarax “Gobsmack” Allimander Dragonborn Paladin and party daddy scorned by his order for his awkward reinterpretation of his Vows, to not deal with raiding Goblins. Calypso “So-So” Sonder Honorable Human Monk "kabuki luchador" chasing one last hurrah without selling out to vulgarity, Hogs party protein, but always apologizes. Cog-Stool Warforged Spore Druid, a strange two-minded chimera born of centuries of quiet interfacing between a decommissioned battledroid prototype and an awakened mycelial network. Clover Medley Tiefling Ranger. Charming farmgirl from a loving home in a deeply cursed valley, obsessed with chasing an alleged blighted Kirin. Wrangles Abyssal pigs and creeps out the cityfolk. Donner Harengon Battle Master haunted by the apprentice he sacrificed to escape a Revenant; keeps others alive with blunt advice and kale stew. Geldok Iron Tusk Soft-gutted Orc ex-raider turned unlikely Cleric of the mysterious "Big Boss"; streetcorner problem solver and healer, who obeys no worldly authority. Harold Carnap Halfling Warlock grandpa. Devilishly wholesome, turning blood rituals to potlucks. Possibly an evil genius in a cardigan. The jury is still out. Iblit Calvin & Hobbes meets Good Omens: An orphaned teen Kobold Celestial Warlock bound to an archangel who hates this assignment as much as he does. Mahorran The undertide A corporate Marid's one-woman pirate crew grinding it out on the high seas for that sweet promotion to branch manager. Precious about her working conditions and depressingly uneventful downtime. Orfan Firbolg Archaeologist whose questionable scientific methods landed him Draconic Sorcery powers. Torn between the call of the wild and the academy that failed him. Lia Amberhorn Satyr Wild Magic Sorcerer who believes in her own stereotypes. Rejected by her sober, ableist merchant family, but still snipes with pinpoint precision, whether with word or spell. Inakha Nulakiano Conservative Goliath working-class Ranger chasing culinary redemption armed with a greataxe, a mysterious cookbook, and the emotional regulation skills of an average toddler. Salynna "Sally" Tarrant Trickster Paladin who stole cutlery at the boarding school for ten years before she found her purpose in life; now smothers her sworn Ward with an overreach of steel and cunning. Scarecrow Warforged Bard who stood guard in a village square for centuries, quietly indexing every life and family tree. Gives great hugs. Also spies on you. Sister Garra Tiny Tabaxi Trickster Cleric of the illegal slum order the Mud Nuns. Smuggles refugees and leaves receipts of spiritual unclogging with those she robs. Stennart Goldgift Meidocre Dwarf merchant accidentally turned overnight Hercules. Slowly transforming into a World Tree seedling, but still clings to the strength that finally made him feel significant. Tormin Remus "Guy Faust", a revolutionary who sold his soul and face to become the perfect insurrectionist, the pied piper of the smallfolk. Yawp Cumuluni Goliath Bard raised in silence, now a one-woman moshpit who plays bagpipes in thunderstorms and lives to be the hype machine that forces an echo from the world.

Locations: - Lith and Flesh, a decadent boutique where petrified objects and creatures are modified and sold at premium rates. Tone: Satire, Body horror, Comedy. Includes Jeremy, the NPC that refuses to die.

Factions: - The Mud Nuns, a barefoot mendicant order of nuns living for mercy through mischief and larceny in the slums of the City. Tone: Heists, Divine trickstery, Urban Intrigue. Includes Sister Garra, PC/NPC who leaves receipts of "karma rebalanced" with her victims.

  • (More sections coming: one-shots, campaign seeds, bestiaries, etc.)

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text:
Why are there AI-generated images? Mood images and visual aids are AI-generated to convey vibes. They’re non-essential and you're free to ignore them. The concepts and writing are original.

Is this PG-13? Yes. Most content works for younger audiences or can easily be tweaked, but check notes on each page. Any trigger warnings appear on the relevant character pages.

How are the characters designed? All characters are designed to slot in seamlessly at many tables:

  • Level 5
  • Built in the official character creator at dndbeyond.com
  • All ability scores are taken with the Points buy method.
  • Homebrew is marked as such and explained on the character page.
  • Characters are built with respect for both narrative weight and game efficiency; they are not "mechanically optimized".
  • PDF's are clean sheets taken directly from dndbeyond.com. They do not include all the info on the character page because: 1) it wouldn't fit, 2) it leaves space for the players to take notes.

Take what you want, discard, rebuild or remix the rest.

Built with ❤️ using MkDocs and GitHub Pages. Repo: https://github.com/Oenig138/STI • Contact: oenig@protonmail.com • Open to collaborations.

docs.title: The City of the Wheel — Water Clock
docs.text: Purpose: To track the city’s survival time and escalating consequences when the Decanter of Endless Water is stolen, sabotaged, or fails.

docs.title: Base Assumptions
docs.text:
• Population: ~45,000–50,000
  • Daily Water Needs (with rationing): 10 gallons/person/day (~450,000 gallons/day)
  • Stored Reserves: ~1.5 million gallons (3–4 days of rationed supply in cisterns)
  • Green Belt Buffer: Can sustain minimal food production for up to 2 weeks without the Decanter, but requires water to stay viable.

docs.title: Clock Settings
docs.text:
Choose a starting point depending on the crisis:

Scenario Starting Point Reason Sudden Theft (Decanter gone) Day 1 No production, only stored reserves remain Gradual Decline (output reduced) Varies GM sets drop rate; extend timeline proportionally Sabotage / Contamination Day 0–1 May need to halt distribution immediately to prevent illness

docs.title: Daily Countdown & Effects
docs.text: Day Water Supply Citywide Effect Day 1 75% reserves Rations tightened, outer ring taps run half days only. Prices for water tokens double. Day 2 50% reserves Long queues at district towers, desert police increase patrols. Rumors of hoarding. Rebels begin public speeches. Day 3 25% reserves Outer ring on emergency rations. First fights break out at cistern lines. Order announces martial law in some districts. Day 4 10% reserves Outer ring taps closed entirely. Riots in poor districts; rebels openly defy Order patrols. Inner ring begins hoarding. Day 5 5% reserves Green belt irrigation halted. Crops start wilting. City gates closed to prevent mass exodus. Executions for water theft. Day 6 2% reserves Disease begins spreading from contaminated standing water. Bodies in the streets. Rebel cells seize or sabotage aqueducts. Day 7 0% reserves Full collapse: green belt dead, outer ring abandoned. Order retreats to palace district with remaining stores. Civil war or mass die-off inevitable.

docs.title: Modifiers
docs.text:
• Green Belt Buffer: Add +2 days before complete collapse if the crisis starts at the beginning of the planting season.
  • Weather Miracle: A rare desert storm can reset the clock by +1 day (also makes for a dramatic story beat).
  • Rebel Control: If rebels seize a district tower, they may redistribute water — this can save lives in that district but hastens collapse elsewhere.
  • Well Discovery: Finding a deep well or ancient cistern can buy 12–24 hours of time.

docs.title: GM Tips
docs.text:
• Show, Don’t Tell: Describe physical signs each day — cracked lips, dust in the air, dried fountains, wilting palms, the stench of unwashed bodies.
  • Escalate Conflict: The later the day, the more desperate every faction becomes.
  • Faction Opportunism: Even as the city nears collapse, both the Order and the Thirstless will try to leverage the crisis to cement long-term power.
  • Tighten the Clock: If you want a high-pressure session, start at Day 3 instead of Day 1.

When the Water Clock reaches Day 7 without restoration, the City of the Wheel ceases to function as a political entity — whatever remains will be something entirely new.

docs.title: Five Philosophical Adventures in the City of the Wheel
docs.text:
“Water is not given. Water is taken. And those who take it decide who lives.” — Graffiti scrawled near Cistern Tower Seven, Outer Ring

The City of the Wheel is not a dungeon to be looted, but a society to be interrogated. Below are five fully developed scenarios designed for roleplay-heavy tables, where dialogue, moral compromise, and political maneuvering carry more weight than sword swings. Each scenario leverages the Water Clock, factional tensions, and the existential dread of the Decanter’s absence to force players into impossible choices—choices that reveal not just what their characters can do, but what they are willing to become.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The PCs are hired by a reformist priest-engineer to sabotage the Rain Room during a state ceremony—not to destroy it, but to expose its waste. But when the levers jam and the entire city goes dry, they must choose: restore flow to save lives, or let the city suffer to break the Order’s grip.

docs.title: Background
docs.text: High Priest-Engineer Veylan is hosting the “Blessing of the Sands” ceremony, inviting foreign dignitaries to bathe in the Rain Room as a show of divine favor. Meanwhile, Sister Elira, a disillusioned mid-level engineer-priest, believes the spectacle is sacrilege—and a perfect moment to sabotage the diversion mechanism. She hires the PCs to infiltrate the Source Tower’s lower maintenance shafts and jam the Rain Room levers mid-ceremony, forcing the water to flow to the city instead.

docs.title: Factions & NPCs
docs.text:
• Sister Elira (Reformist Priest-Engineer): Believes the Order can be redeemed from within. She wants to shame Veylan, not overthrow him. “Let them see the cost of their vanity,” she whispers. But she didn’t plan for the levers to break.
  • High Priest Veylan: Charismatic, ruthless. Uses the Rain Room not for luxury, but as psychological warfare. If the flow stops, he will blame “foreign saboteurs” and execute dissidents.
  • District Overseer Kael (Outer Ring): A pragmatist. If water stops flowing, he’ll open his district’s emergency cistern—but only if the PCs help him “disappear” the Order’s guards first.

docs.title: Player Choices & Dilemmas
docs.text:
• Do they fix the jammed mechanism to restore water, betraying Elira’s cause?
  • Do they let the city dry out for 12–24 hours to maximize political impact, knowing children will die of thirst?
  • Do they side with Kael to seize control of a district cistern—becoming de facto warlords in the chaos?
  • Do they expose Elira to Veylan to save themselves, condemning her to ritual drowning in the Rain Room?

docs.title: Water Clock & Consequences
docs.text:
• Starts at Day 0 — Sabotage halts all flow. City enters emergency state immediately.
  • Day 1: Riots begin in Outer Ring. Veylan declares martial law.
  • Day 2: If flow not restored, disease spreads. Kael offers PCs water in exchange for loyalty.
  • Consequence A (Flow Restored): Elira is executed. Veylan tightens control. PCs branded traitors by rebels.
  • Consequence B (Flow Denied): Outer Ring collapses. Thirstless rise in violent revolt. City enters civil war by Day 4.
  • Consequence C (District Seized): PCs become local heroes—or tyrants. The Order will send an army to retake the tower.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The PCs recover a second Decanter of Endless Water—hidden by one of the original founders. Now, both the Order and the Thirstless demand it. Hand it over, and you empower tyranny or chaos. Keep it, and you become the most hunted beings in the desert.

docs.title: Background
docs.text: An ancient map, etched on sun-bleached bone, leads to a buried shrine in the dunes. There, the PCs find a second Decanter—identical to the one in the Source Tower. The dying founder who hid it whispers: “I knew they’d turn it into a throne. I left this… for the people.” But word leaks. The Order sends assassins. The Thirstless send envoys. Both promise rewards. Both threaten annihilation.

docs.title: Factions & NPCs
docs.text:
• Brother Silas (Thirstless Envoy): A former engineer, now rebel. He pleads: “Give us the Decanter. We’ll build a new tower in the Outer Ring. No more masters.” But his faction has no engineers left. They’ll likely break it.
  • Inquisitor Mareth (Order of the Wheel): Cold, logical. Offers the PCs noble titles, inner-ring estates, and lifetime water rights. “Chaos is the true enemy. Stability requires hierarchy.” Secretly plans to destroy the second Decanter once acquired.
  • The Grey Market Water Baron: Offers 50,000 gold pieces and safe passage out of the city—for the Decanter. “Let the fools kill each other. Profit is the only true flow.”

docs.title: Player Choices & Dilemmas
docs.text:
• Give it to the Thirstless? You may ignite a revolution—but without technical knowledge, they’ll likely destroy it or get slaughtered trying to install it.
  • Give it to the Order? You stabilize the city—but condemn it to another 50 years of theocratic control. Mareth will lie to you.
  • Sell it? You profit, but doom the city to its fate—or worse, empower a warlord who uses it to conquer neighboring lands.
  • Hide it? You become fugitives. The Water Clock doesn’t start… yet. But the city’s slow decay continues. And someone will find it.

docs.title: Water Clock & Consequences
docs.text:
• No immediate countdown — unless the PCs trigger a crisis (e.g., destroy the original Decanter).
  • But: The city is already on Day 1 of slow decay due to population growth outpacing infrastructure. Every week without action, subtract 1 day from reserves.
  • If PCs give Decanter to Thirstless: Water Clock pauses—but after 48 hours, if rebels fail to install it properly, restart at Day 2 with riots.
  • If PCs give it to Order: Water Clock resets to Day 7—but rationing tightens further. Dissent is crushed. PCs live in gilded cages.
  • If PCs destroy or hide it: City continues slow collapse. PCs are hunted. The desert remembers.

docs.title: 3. The Thirstless Uprising (And the Well That Wasn’t)
Summary
docs.text: The Thirstless seize Cistern Tower Four—but discover its reserves are poisoned. The PCs, caught in the middle, must broker a truce between rebels and the Order to save thousands… or let them die to prove a point.

docs.title: Background
docs.text: The Thirstless, emboldened by rumors of the PCs’ exploits, launch a coordinated attack on Cistern Tower Four. They win—but find the cistern laced with bitterroot extract (non-lethal but causes vomiting and dehydration). The Order claims it was rebel sabotage. The rebels claim it was a trap. Both are lying. The truth? A low-level clerk poisoned it to create a martyrdom event.

docs.title: Factions & NPCs
docs.text:
• Razek, Thirstless Commander: Idealistic but out of his depth. “We hold the tower! The people will rally!” But his medics are overwhelmed. He begs the PCs for help purifying the water—or finding a new source.
  • Clerk Nessa (Secret Poisoner): Quiet, fanatical. Believes only mass suffering will “awaken” the people. “Let them die thirsty. Then they will rise like dunes in a storm.” She’s prepared to die for her cause.
  • Captain Dain (Desert Police): Ordered to retake the tower “at all costs.” But he has family in the district. “I don’t want to burn this place down. Help me find another way.”

docs.title: Player Choices & Dilemmas
docs.text:
• Do they help Razek purify the water (requiring rare alchemical components and time), knowing it legitimizes the rebellion?
  • Do they negotiate with Captain Dain for a ceasefire and joint investigation—risking being seen as traitors by both sides?
  • Do they expose Nessa? She’ll be executed—but her martyrdom may ignite wider revolt.
  • Do they let the district suffer, believing the ends justify the means?

docs.title: Water Clock & Consequences
docs.text:
• Starts at Day 3 for District Four only. Citywide clock remains at Day 1.
  • Day 4 (District): 20% dead from dehydration. Riots spread to neighboring districts.
  • If PCs broker truce: District saved. Water Clock pauses. But the Order uses the “rebel poisoning” as propaganda—cracking down citywide.
  • If PCs help purify water: Thirstless gain legitimacy. Order declares open war. Citywide Water Clock advances to Day 2.
  • If PCs do nothing: District Four dies. Thirstless movement fractures. Order consolidates power. Water Clock advances to Day 3 citywide.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The dying Voice of the Source summons the PCs. He admits the Decanter is failing—and offers them the throne. But accepting means inheriting a lie: the “divine” artifact is a cursed relic, and its magic is draining the life from the land.

docs.title: Background
docs.text: The Voice, Veylan’s predecessor, is bedridden, skin like cracked clay. He reveals the truth: the Decanter isn’t divine. It’s a relic from a drowned empire, powered by a bound water elemental that is slowly dying. Every gallon drawn accelerates the desert’s spread. He ruled knowing this. Now he offers the PCs his seat: “Fix what I could not. Or let it all turn to dust.”

docs.title: Factions & NPCs
docs.text:
• The Dying Voice: Haunted, remorseful. “We called it a blessing. It was a theft—from the earth itself.” He wants redemption, not survival.
  • High Engineer Veylan (Heir Apparent): Doesn’t know the truth. Believes the Decanter is eternal. Will kill to protect the lie. “The people need faith, not facts.”
  • The Bound Elemental (Whispering through pipes): Not evil—exhausted. Communicates in dreams and dripping echoes: “Free me… or let me sleep.”

docs.title: Player Choices & Dilemmas
docs.text:
• Accept the throne? You must either perpetuate the lie—or reveal the truth and risk total collapse.
  • Destroy the Decanter? You doom the city—but free the elemental and halt the desert’s unnatural spread.
  • Seek a third way? Perhaps bind a new elemental? Or find a natural aquifer? Both require time the city doesn’t have.
  • Side with Veylan? You become the new face of the lie. The elemental’s whispers will haunt you.

docs.title: Water Clock & Consequences
docs.text:
• Starts at Day 5 — The Decanter’s output has already slowed by 40%. The Voice hid it.
  • Day 6: Elemental’s whispers become audible citywide. Madness spreads.
  • If PCs accept throne and reveal truth: Mass panic. Water Clock accelerates. +1 Day per 24 hours.
  • If PCs destroy Decanter: Elemental freed. Desert stops expanding. City dies in 7 days. PCs become legends—or monsters.
  • If PCs bind new elemental: Requires a sentient sacrifice. Who volunteers? Who is chosen?

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The Order offers the PCs a deal: execute the Thirstless leadership, and they’ll divert water to expand the Green Belt—saving thousands from starvation. But the rebels offer the same deal in reverse: help them assassinate the Voice, and they’ll open the cisterns to all. Who do you betray to save more lives?

docs.title: Background
docs.text: The Green Belt—the city’s breadbasket—is failing. Without more water, famine looms in 30 days. The Order can save it… but only if “stability” is ensured (i.e., the Thirstless are crushed). The Thirstless can open the cisterns to feed the poor… but only if the Voice is removed. Both sides offer the PCs wealth, power, and moral absolution. Both are lying about the scale of their promises.

docs.title: Factions & NPCs
docs.text:
• Voice of the Source: “Kill Razek and his council. I will sign the irrigation decree myself.” But the decree has loopholes—it only waters loyalist farms.
  • Razek (Thirstless): “Kill Veylan during the Rain Room ceremony. We’ll flood the Outer Ring with water.” But the Thirstless have no control over the aqueducts—they’ll break them trying.
  • Farmer-Lia (Green Belt Representative): Pragmatic. “I don’t care who rules. Just keep the water flowing. Or we all starve.” She’ll betray anyone to save her crops.

docs.title: Player Choices & Dilemmas
docs.text:
• Side with the Order? You become executioners. The Green Belt expands—but only for the elite. The Outer Ring starves.
  • Side with the Thirstless? You become regicides. The cisterns open—but without engineers, the system floods and breaks. Half the city drowns; half dies of thirst.
  • Play both sides? You might buy time—but when discovered, both factions will hunt you.
  • Refuse both? The Green Belt dies. Famine hits in 30 days. Water Clock advances 1 day per week of inaction.

docs.title: Water Clock & Consequences
docs.text:
• Starts at Day 1 — But the Famine Clock is ticking separately (30 days).
  • If PCs side with Order: Famine Clock pauses. Water Clock resets to Day 7—but Outer Ring enters permanent drought. Rebellion goes underground.
  • If PCs side with Thirstless: Famine Clock pauses. Water Clock resets—but after 48 hours, aqueducts rupture. Restart at Day 3 with flooding.
  • If PCs refuse: Famine Clock reaches Day 30. Mass starvation. Water becomes irrelevant. City collapses into cannibal clans.

In the City of the Wheel, there are no clean hands—only wet ones and dry ones. Choose whose thirst you will quench. And whose you will ignore.

docs.title: The City of the Wheel
docs.text: A 50-year-old theocratic city-state in the deep desert, sustained entirely by a single magical artifact — the Decanter of Endless Water.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
In the dead heart of the Saharan sands rises The City of the Wheel, a walled and tiered settlement fed by a single Decanter of Endless Water. This magical artifact, housed in the Source Tower at the city’s heart, provides the only lifeline to tens of thousands of inhabitants.

Over fifty years, the city has grown from a happy retirement project of a band of adventurers into a tightly controlled priest-engineer theocracy. Water is life, law, and currency here — and those who control it rule absolutely.

docs.title: The Decanter of Endless Water
docs.text:
• Location: Sacred chamber at the top of the Source Tower.
  • Function: Produces 30 gallons of fresh water every 6 seconds (combat time), amounting to ~432,000 gallons per day.
  • Access: Only the Order of the Wheel may touch or adjust it.
  • Security: Heavily guarded day and night by elite desert police and engineer-priests.
  • Symbolism: Referred to as “The Source,” believed to be divine in origin. To threaten it is high heresy.

docs.title: The Rain Room
docs.text:
Directly beneath the Decanter lies the Holy Rain Room — the most sacred place in the city.

  • Design: Circular chamber with a golden mesh floor, beneath which a cistern collects water.
  • Mechanism: A system of levers above can divert the Decanter’s flow entirely into the Rain Room, cutting off water to the rest of the city.
  • Ceremony: Bathing here is the city’s greatest honor, granted only to the ruler, high clergy, victorious generals, or foreign dignitaries.
  • Impact: When the Rain Room is active, the whole city knows — aqueducts run dry, and the absence of water reinforces the Order’s power.

docs.title: Governance: The Order of the Wheel
docs.text: The Order is a closed, hereditary caste of priest-engineers who: - Maintain the aqueduct system. - Oversee city expansion and water allocation. - Control population growth and immigration. - Punish dissent by cutting water to individual districts.

docs.title: Political Nature
docs.text:
• Structure: The Voice of the Source (high priest-engineer) rules as both spiritual leader and chief hydraulic authority.
  • Enforcement: A strong, disciplined Desert Police protect the Source Tower, patrol aqueducts, and guard the green belt.
  • Corruption: Water rations are political tools; loyal districts get excess during festivals, rebellious ones get their taps sealed.

docs.title: The Thirstless — Rebel Movement
docs.text: Motto: Water for all, without the Wheel

docs.title: Beliefs
docs.text:
• Water is a divine gift meant for everyone, not the property of the priest-engineers.
  • The Rain Room is an obscene waste, an idol to tyranny.
  • The green belt should be expanded until no one goes hungry.

docs.title: Reality
docs.text:
• Strengths: Popular support in the outer ring, hidden caches of weapons, and a few sympathetic lower-ranking engineers.
  • Weaknesses: Poor organization, no infrastructure to protect the Decanter if seized.
  • Risk: A poorly planned seizure could lead to the Order retaking the Decanter within hours, using the rebellion as an excuse for mass repression.

docs.title: History: 50 Years in Brief
docs.text: Year Event 0–5 Founders (retired adventurers) build a fortified village around the Decanter. Water is free and plentiful. 6–15 Population surges as news spreads. Informal water wardens appear. First disputes over allocation. 16–25 Water wardens formalize into the Order of the Wheel. Public service shifts to bureaucratic control. 26–30 Coup during a crisis. Remaining founders killed or exiled. Voice of the Source installed. 31–50 Full theocratic consolidation. Rain Room rituals begin. Expansion of palace district and covered aqueducts. Green belt established. Rebel murmurs grow in the outer ring.

docs.title: The Source Tower and Aqueducts
docs.text:
Source Tower - Tallest structure in the city, visible for miles. - Whitewashed walls and inlaid mosaics of palm trees, waves, and rivers. - Upper gardens reserved for the ruling elite.

Aqueducts - Seven covered channels radiate outward from the tower, sloping slightly downwards. - Each ends in a district cistern tower. - Covered design prevents evaporation and sabotage.

docs.title: The City Layout (Year 50)
docs.text:
1. Core: Walled palace district with the Source Tower, Rain Room, and ceremonial gardens.
  2. Inner Ring: Wealthy merchant and artisan quarters with private cisterns and shaded courtyards.
  3. Outer Ring: Dense poor districts, communal taps, strict rationing, heavy police patrols, strong rebel presence.
  4. Beyond the Walls: Shanty towns, seasonal markets, green belt farms, and dew harvesting stations.

docs.title: Water Recycling and Daily Life
docs.text: Water is recycled and reused obsessively: - Greywater Systems: Used bath and kitchen water filtered through reed beds and reused for irrigation. - Blackwater Composting: Nightsoil collected, composted, and used in green belt farms. - Aquaponics: Fish tanks feed vegetable beds in closed loops, minimizing evaporation. - Dew Harvesters: Mesh structures collect morning condensation for supplemental use. - Palm Tree Avenues: Shade streets, bind soil, and reduce surface evaporation.

docs.title: Sights and Sounds for Adventurers
docs.text:
• Women scrubbing laundry at public cisterns, their waste water funneled into vegetable beds.
  • Guards locking down a district tower, and desperate residents pleading for mercy.
  • The sudden silence when the Rain Room is in use — no water flowing, the whole city holding its breath.
  • Shady courtyards where water trickles into stone basins, guarded by armed retainers.
  • Outer markets selling ceramic water tokens redeemable at district taps.

docs.title: The Theft of the Source
docs.text:
• High-Level: A desert dragon steals the Decanter to create its own oasis. PCs must pursue it before the city collapses.
  • Low–Mid-Level: A rival city-state hires thieves to steal the Decanter during the Rain Room ceremony.

docs.title: Rebel Gambit
docs.text:
• PCs recover the Decanter — and the Thirstless beg for it to be handed over to them.
  • Moral dilemma: stability under tyranny, chaos under hope, or keeping it themselves.

docs.title: The False Flow
docs.text: • The Decanter is swapped for an illusion or a Decanter of Endless Saltwater. PCs must find the real one before contamination spreads.

docs.title: Coup in the Wheel
docs.text: • A faction in the Order cuts water to certain districts to force political change. PCs are hired to restore the flow or protect key cistern towers.

docs.title: The Elder’s Secret
docs.text:
• A dying founder hints at a second Decanter hidden in the desert. The Order and rebels both seek it — for very different reasons.

The City of the Wheel thrives, but its heart beats to the rhythm of falling water. Without the Source, the desert will reclaim it in weeks — and someone will decide who lives and who dies.

docs.title: The Blackwell Legacy
docs.text:
Among the dwarves of the Blackwell Clan, a warrior's shield is a vessel of memory, duty, and spirit. When a Blackwell warrior falls, their comrades are bound by sacred duty to retrieve their shield, even if the body is lost. A fragment of the fallen’s soul is believed to cling to the shield, and to leave it behind is to leave the dead untethered.

If the shield is destroyed beyond repair, what remains is reforged into a Griefshield, a replacement acknowledged, but never quite the same. Griefshields are hung with solemn reverence and never placed above a cradle.

Upon return, the shield is placed in the Sanctum Alcove for a full year of mourning. Shieldsmiths, part artisan and part priest, tend to it with oil, prayer, and memory carvings. During this time, the family offers libations, stories, and burn memory scrolls to prepare the spirit for its next bearer.

When the year has passed, the shield is reborn into service. The clerics, with guidance from augury and the shieldsmith, assign it to a newborn whose cradle is crowned with the shield. From that moment, it will be with them until death. A Blackwell shield is thus witness to the full arc of a life, from the nursery to the battlefield.

Each shield bears the engraved names of its previous bearers, some faded, others freshly scored, forming a line of remembrance carried into every battle. The shields hang in rows within the clan’s meadhall between lifetimes, each waiting for a match, each a library of stories etched in steel and splinters.

“You do not carry the shield. The shield carries you, and you carry your clan.”

docs.title: Back to the Couture
docs.text:
"I find myself... incommensurably obliged."

A time-heist one-shot about sacred objects, disproportionate responses, and the small regrets we'd undo if we could.

Keywords: Character-driven, low-stakes premise, high-stakes emotions, heist, time travel, comedy, bottle episode

docs.title: The Setup
docs.text:
The party has befriended a weathered career grifter—someone who taught them (or one of them) the practical curriculum of the crooked life: lockpicks, cold reading, sleeping rough, and slipping away unseen. He's transactional but reliable, operating by "honor among thieves" rules he's never once romanticized. He wears an ostentatiously fine (and large) hat he's transparently proud of. He peppers his speech with elaborate vocabulary he may or may not be using ironically anymore.

Then, one day, he finds the party, and he is a changed man. Grim, intense, bloodthirsty, speaking in clipped sentences. The flowery language replaced with the winds of winter. They notice his hat is missing.

Slowly they realize this man is fully prepared to kill over a hat. Not because he's snapped, but because the hat was the one thing. The one line. And someone crossed it.

Anyone in the party who's known real poverty would likely understand immediately. When you've got nothing, you pick one thing and hold it sacred. The rest of the party might laugh, or try to talk him down, suggest he just buy a new hat. Someone has to decide whether to translate for them or let them fumble through it.

The objective is simple: Find the people who stole the hat.

The complication: The thieves were actually a guild of Fire Elementals on sightseeing through the Material Plane, disguised with strong Illusion spells. As the party approaches, one of them laughs: "This ugly thing?" and incinerates the hat in front of their eyes. Like a child popping a balloon.

docs.title: The Sane Option: The Replica
docs.text:
Track down whoever made the original, source the materials, commission something identical. This is the reasonable path—investigation, craftsmanship, perhaps a small fetch quest for rare components (who the hell decided to put an actual Griffin feather in this haberdashery of a hat?).

But the grifter will know. He'll wear it, he'll thank them, and he'll know it's not the same hat. Objectively speaking, the new one is better, but the spell is broken. The transaction will be complete and things will be... fine.

This path works if your table prefers grounded problem-solving. It's still satisfying—there's detective work, maybe some confrontation with the fire elementals, and a bittersweet ending where everyone pretends the replacement is enough.

docs.title: The Correct Option: The Time Heist
docs.text:
Steal a super-experimental one-use-only time-travelling scroll. Go back, save the hat, save the timeline.

This is insane and therefore the correct choice.

The scroll should be stolen from someone who will absolutely come looking for it later—a solitary archmage, a BBEG from a previous campaign, a powerful entity the party has unfinished business with, or their local rival who they always mess with. The party burns a cosmic favor to save a hat. They travel back exactly one week, to the day before the hat was stolen, and must extract the hat, of course without disrupting the timeline or running into their past selves (otherwise immense psychic damage).

docs.title: The Regret Mechanic
docs.text:
Here's where the one-shot becomes something more.

If you want to build toward this adventure in advance, seed "small regrets" into that special day they traveled back to. Nothing campaign-altering—just the kind of thing that nags at you:

  • A harsh word to an ally they wish they could take back
  • A deal they made that felt wrong the moment they shook hands
  • Information they didn't share in time
  • A stranger they didn't help when they could have
  • A moment of cowardice they've been replaying in their head

The time heist gives them the chance to go back and fix these things. But the scroll imposes constraints—they only have until sundown (or whatever limit suits your table). They cannot fix everything. So they have to triage their regrets in real time, negotiating which personal cringe is worth spending their dwindling hours on.

The drama (and comedy) writes itself: the party splits up trying to accomplish different micro-corrections while also protecting the hat from a bunch of disguised fire elemental tourists. Someone inevitably makes things worse. Someone fixes their small regret but causes a new problem for someone else. Someone realizes they can't actually change the thing they wanted to change because their past self needs to experience it, and it's actually fine.

The hat is the mission objective, but the hat is also the excuse, the thing that lets them admit to each other: "Actually, there's something else I'd want to undo while we're here..."

docs.title: The Resolution
docs.text: They return the original hat. The grifter puts it on. He doesn't ask how. He doesn't want to know. He just nods, says something like "I find myself... incommensurably obliged," and the mask is back on. But it's real this time.

docs.title: Running This Adventure
docs.text:
Best used: After your party has been together long enough to have accumulated small interpersonal friction and minor regrets. This works as a breather between heavy story arcs, or as a character-focused session when you need a break from the main plot.

Tone: Comedy on the surface, genuine emotion underneath. Think Groundhog Day meets a caper film. The absurdity of the premise makes the real character moments feel somehow more real.

The grifter NPC: Adapt to your campaign. He works best if the party already knows and likes him—someone who's helped them before, who operates by his own code, who they've seen be competent and sardonic. If you're using the Alveta "Velvet" character from this bundle, Alphonse Collier fills this role naturally.

Time travel rules: Keep them simple. One-way trip back, fixed return point, no meeting your past selves (or immediate paradox/ejection from the timeline). The constraint creates the tension; don't let the mechanics become the focus.

The fire elementals: They're not supposed to be villains you actually fight, just obnoxious tourists who genuinely don't understand why anyone would care about such an ugly hat. The one who burned it was simply being a dismissive asshole, not out to pick an actual fight. Don't let the party kill them without consequences; they're just idiots on vacation.

docs.title: The Snipper
docs.text: A horror investigation one-shot

docs.title: Content Warning
docs.text: Body horror (progressive amputation), colonial violence, psychological manipulation, cultural erasure, acute risk for Arachnophobia. Conduct Session Zero accordingly.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: A nobleman hires the party to investigate an impossible curse: each night at midnight, everyone in his manor falls into supernatural sleep, and he wakes missing another extremity—fingers, then toes, then limbs—each wound cleanly cauterized and painless. What begins as a locked-room mystery unfolds into a confrontation with an ancient dream-predator and forces the party to navigate the bitter consequences of colonial violence.

docs.title: The Victim
docs.text:
Lord Aldric Thorne, decorated veteran of colonial "pacification" campaigns. Twenty years ago, he was assigned to secure indigenous territory for Crown resource extraction. His final assignment involved a coastal people called the dreamstriders—neighbors avoided their territory and spoke of them as "sleepwalkers."

Thorne remembers the operation beginning. He remembers the dreamstriders offering almost no resistance. He remembers growing deeply disturbed without understanding why. Then his memories fragment. He requested immediate transfer home, couldn't explain the decision then, can't explain it now.

What really happened, which he doesn't consciously remember, is that he made a bargain in the Dream.

docs.title: The Dreamstriders
docs.text:
The dreamstriders possess a unique cultural technology. In their particular bay grows a sacred kelp. Properly prepared through techniques refined over generations, it allows them to enter a collective dreamspace—a traversable realm adjacent to waking reality. Their leadership makes binding decisions there. Their elders maintain cultural memory in dream-architecture persisting independent of individual minds, a paradise of their own making.

But this gift came with ancient warnings. The Dream was not theirs alone. In its depths dwelt things that were never human—entities for whom dream-logic was natural law and human consciousness was prey. The dreamstriders survived by staying in mapped safe regions, never venturing into the Deep, where monsters lived. They raised collective barriers around their sanctified space in the Dreamspace.

docs.title: The Coast Leaf
docs.text:
A weaker relative of the sacred kelp grew wild throughout the coastal region. Local peoples used it medicinally and ceremonially, with careful preparation to extract pain-relieving properties while minimizing psychoactive effects.

Colonial forces saw a resource to extract. They discovered the wild kelp's opiate properties and began crude harvesting. Soldiers smoked it recreationally, seeking relief from the psychological weight of their work. They called it "coast leaf" and treated it as harmless vice.

They had no idea what they were opening themselves to, officers smoking bastardized dream-plant while committing atrocities. Their preparation was crude, dried it too quickly, burned it at wrong temperatures, consumed without proper intention. Instead of enabling controlled Dream navigation, it thinned the membrane between waking consciousness and the Dream just enough for something patient and predatory to slip whispers through.

One such mind, and arguably the most ancient and powerful of them all, is named Moghara. The combination of altered states, accumulated trauma, and suppressed guilt created perfect conditions. She carefully planted strategic insights, tactical inspirations, a growing conviction that the sleepwalker people represented a threat requiring immediate action.

Lord Thorne was a regular user. His campaign journal shows the pattern, if the players find it: entries mentioning smoking are followed within days by frantic entries expressing unease about "strategic vulnerabilities" and "elements we haven't fully pacified." He never connected the two.

docs.title: Moghara
docs.text:
The entity called Moghara manifests as a spider, abiding in the darkness between sleeping minds for longer than human memory. She had wanted access to the dreamstriders for generations—their technology represented the most sophisticated human navigation of her domain she'd ever encountered. But their elders were wise. They stayed away from the depths, erected barriers against her influence.

Through officers like Aldric Thorne she engineered a situation where they'd have no choice but to come to her. Facing cultural erasure from colonial violence, the dreamstriders broke their ancestors' prohibitions. They ventured into the Deep Dream seeking the only power that might save them. They negotiated their future with the Dream Queen under duress.

She granted protection against the very problem she had secretly created: She would turn Thorne's mind against his mission, compelling him to leave. The price would be one dreamer per generation sent to serve as her anchor in their people. She'd get to listen in, study their ways, and the anchor would be her steward and carry out her will in the material world. The Dreamstriders would maintain this bargain forever.

docs.title: The Contract
docs.text:
Again, Moghara visited Thorne in his dreams, appearing as a beautiful woman offering escape from his disturbing assignment. She offered wealth, status, safe return home. The price: leave these shores immediately and never return to "his ways." Thorne accepted. Moghara granted exactly what she promised: inexplicable compulsion to request transfer, subsequent success, lands and title. Then she erased his memory of the bargain.

He took up landed nobility, and for fifteen years he prospered, remembering and avoiding the atrocities of his time in the colonies. But neighboring lords snickered at his ways, looking down on him as "weak" against his people. Afraid that a reputation of weakness would end up with him getting invaded by neighboring lords, he began systematically enclosing common lands, enforcing ruthless rents and tithes, converting communal resources to private holdings.

Against his will, he was replicating exactly the extractive violence he'd performed overseas—the same work in a new location. The contract was thus violated. Moghara began collection.

docs.title: The Trophy Wife
docs.text:
Lord Thorne also brought back a wife from overseas. Lady Isra Thorne was presented as a willing bride, and living proof of "successful cultural integration". She comes from the dreamstriders, and did what she did for her people—performed attraction, encouraged his affection, made herself into someone he wanted to bring home. The manipulation was for survival, as a failsafe if the deal with Moghara fell out. It was also maybe a bit too effective. Lord Thorne fell genuinely in love.

Even today, he showers her with gifts and introduces her proudly to his peers. He cannot understand why, the moment they reached his homeland, she turned to ice. He complains to anyone who'll listen that she led him on, that he's tried everything, that he doesn't know what he did wrong. His confusion is sincere and his hurt is real, and neither fact entitles him to anything. He cannot perceive that his "love" was a cage she built around herself to escape a worse one.

For fifteen years Isra has performed dutiful spouse while nursing profound bitterness. Hidden in her chambers is dried kelp from her homeland—the sacred plant. Several nights monthly, she prepares it and dreams with her people across the ocean.

She knows all about Moghara and the terrible bargain. She also understands her husband's dismemberment is both punishment and demonstration—a message to anyone who might break their contracts. She watches him lose pieces of himself with barely concealed satisfaction.

docs.title: The Nightly Ritual
docs.text:
Every midnight, Moghara pulls everyone in the manor into collective dreamspace. In the Dream, they stand in a circle around Thorne's paralyzed form. The dreamstriders appear as compelled witnesses, forced to watch what happens to those who break bargains. Moghara manifests and performs collection: one extremity at a time, wounds cauterizing instantly.

The amputation occurs in the Dream but manifests on his physical body, because the contract allows Moghara power in domains otherwise closed to her. Everyone involved wakes with fragmented memories. Thorne wakes further diminished. But Isra and the Dreamstriders wake knowing exactly what transpired.

docs.title: The Hook
docs.text:
When the party arrives, Aldric Thorne has already lost all ten fingers and has begun losing toes. His hands end in smooth stumps. He does not know what happens next. Does the curse move to claim forearms? Feet? He has at most seven nights before the curse moves on to arms, legs, then finally head, leaving nothing but a surgically cauterized torso, a formless slab of meat.

He has tried everything: Posting guards in the room with him, ingesting powerful potions to stay awake. All witnesses in the castle confirm that they all fall asleep at midnight precisely, with vivid dreams they can't recall clearly. Household staff whisper about curses. Some of the wiser ones have fled.

Lord Thorne offers substantial payment. He's tried everything. Now he suspects the farmers who have been rising up against him may have entered an agreement with a hag, or the Fey. The PC's are asked to go and figure out what is going on.

docs.title: Lord Aldric Thorne
docs.text:
Mid-fifties, once commanding, now diminished and desperate. He genuinely doesn't understand what's happening to him or why. When questioned about Isra, his wounded bewilderment is unfeigned: "I gave her everything. I saved her from that place. And she looks at me like I'm already dead."

He will try to make the party sympathize with his suffering. His suffering is real. It is also the consequence of choices he made and the systems he served.

docs.title: Lady Isra
docs.text:
Dreamstrider woman, mid-thirties, fifteen years performing the role of colonial trophy wife. Cold, observant, technically cooperative. She knows exactly what's happening and wants Thorne dead. She has the sacred kelp hidden in her chambers—the only way for the party to enter the Dream and confront Moghara directly.

She knows her people used coast leaf medicinally. She knows the colonizers misused it. She hasn't connected this to Moghara's manipulation of the colonial campaign—she believes the Crown simply decided to destroy her people, as Crowns do. A perceptive party might help her realize the true scope of how thoroughly she and her people were played.

docs.title: Maren Ashworth
docs.text:
Former smallholder, late forties, now lives in a shanty at the edge of what was once common land. Thorne's enclosure policies destroyed her family's livelihood three years ago. Her husband died the following winter.

Maren leads what the manor calls "the malcontents"—two dozen displaced families who've refused to scatter. They've tried petitioning, then refusing to pay new rents, then making collections dangerous. A factor lost an eye last harvest. One of the Thorne estate's storage barns burned in the spring. Thorne has responded with militia patrols and threats of mass eviction.

Maren is sharp, bitter, and has spent three years learning theory through praxis. She's noticed the parallels: the legal fictions, the gradual appropriation, the way resistance is always framed as the victim's unreasonableness. She doesn't know about the colonies or Isra's people, but she understands extraction.

GM Note on Portrayal: Maren is crucial to the adventure's moral architecture, and her first impression matters enormously. When the party meets her, they should encounter someone who is plainly, unmistakably not a witch, not a schemer, not a mysterious figure trafficking with dark powers. She is a farmwife who lost everything and refused to disappear quietly. Play her as earthy, direct, practical. She spits in her palm before a handshake. She speaks in rural proverbs and hard-won observations rather than ideological abstractions. Her wisdom is the kind that comes from watching seasons turn and landlords lie. When Thorne later accuses "the malcontents" of consorting with hags, players who have met Maren should feel the dissonance immediately: that woman? Working dark magic? This mismatch is the first signal that characters in this adventure do not have the full picture.

The Swann Defection: Maren's leadership has fractured. About half the Malcontents have broken away to seek protection from Lord Duncan Swann, a neighboring nobleman who has made vague promises about "looking into their situation" if they support his territorial ambitions against Thorne. Maren knows this is poison dressed as medicine—Swann is notoriously brutal with his own tenants, and his interest in the Malcontents is purely strategic—but she cannot make her people see it. They are desperate, winter is coming, and Swann is offering something that looks like hope. She has no good counter-offer except continued resistance with no guarantee of success.

This parallel is thematically essential: the Malcontents seeking protection from Swann mirrors the Dreamstriders seeking protection from Moghara. In both cases, a vulnerable people under pressure turn to a power that presents itself as alternative when it is merely another expression of the same extractive logic. Swann didn't create the Malcontents' crisis (Thorne did), but he's happy to exploit it. Moghara did create the Dreamstriders' crisis, which makes her worse—but the structure of the trap is identical.

docs.title: Taalen
docs.text: Dreamstrider, age uncertain—he's lost count. Taalen is the current "anchor," the one dreamer per generation sent to serve Moghara as guide and teacher. He's been in the Dream for eleven years, only allowed to return to his body an hour or so at a time, to make sure the will of Moghara is carried out by the Dreamstriders in the real world. Even then, he's not truly awake as much as his body is a temporary receptacle for Moghara's will.

docs.title: Mosley
docs.text: A scarred colonial veteran with the calm eyes of a man who never stopped being at war; he smokes Coast Leaf to keep his instincts sharp and his conscience quiet, and would rather watch Aldric lose a limb than admit the old order was ever wrong.

docs.title: Petra
docs.text: A gaunt, loyal maid who has sworn to see the house through its doom; she watches Lady Isra with superstitious hatred, yet keeps stumbling onto truths she cannot fully understand, mistaking the scent of kelp and the hush of midnight for witchcraft rather than something far worse.

docs.title: Tracking States
docs.text: Throughout the adventure, track Thorne and Isra's psychological states. Each ends the adventure in one of three states: Hardened, Humbled, or Dead. Keep notes on interactions. When the party makes choices that push toward Hardened or Humbled, mark it. This doesn't need to be numerical—a simple record of "showed him the contract, he couldn't deny it" or "treated her as means to an end" is enough. At resolution, look at your notes and decide what each character has become.

docs.title: Aldric Thorne's Fate
docs.text:
Hardened or Humbled: When confronted with his crimes, does the party offer him a framework for understanding his complicity, or do they simply condemn? Does he face consequences he cannot deny, or accusations he can dismiss as unfair?

Toward Hardened: Accusations without evidence he can verify. Moral condemnation that lets him feel persecuted. Being told he's evil without being shown the mechanism of his harm.

Toward Humbled: Seeing the contract and recognizing his signature. Meeting Maren and hearing what his policies cost in human terms. Learning his "love" for Isra was something she performed to survive. Evidence he cannot dismiss.

docs.title: Isra Thorne's Fate
docs.text:
Hardened or Humbled: Does the party treat her as an instrument, or as a person navigating impossible circumstances? Do they help her see the local farmers as fellow victims, or does she remain focused solely on her own people's suffering?

Toward Hardened: Being treated transactionally. Appeals to "justice" that don't acknowledge what she's lost. Any suggestion that her manipulation of Thorne was morally equivalent to his extraction of her.

Toward Humbled: Genuine solidarity offered without expectation. Connection with Maren that helps her see extraction as a system with many victims. Recognition that she has power now—over the kelp, over information—and choices about how to use it.

docs.title: On the Road
docs.text: The party should encounter Maren before they reach Thorne Manor. This is not optional—the entire moral architecture of the adventure depends on players having a concrete impression of Maren before they hear Thorne's accusations.

docs.title: The Wagon Encounter
docs.text:
As the party travels the road to Thorne's estate, they come upon a cart flanked by four of Thorne's militia. In the back, hands and feet bound, sits a weathered woman in her late forties. The guards are in good spirits, joking about having "caught the ringleader" and speculating about the reward. The woman—Maren—is silent, watching the road behind them with an expression that suggests she's calculating distances rather than despairing.

How the party handles this encounter shapes everything that follows. They might:

Ignore it. The guards aren't breaking any obvious laws. The party has a job to do. This is someone else's problem. If they choose this, they'll learn later that the cart never reached the estate. Maren's people ambushed it, freed her, and melted back into the woods. The guards survived but lost their weapons and dignity.

Intervene. The guards will defer to anyone who looks like they outrank local militia, which adventurers hired by Lord Thorne certainly do. If the party demands Maren's release or even just insists on questioning her themselves, the guards will grumble but comply. This gives the party a chance to actually talk with Maren before the manor's narrative frames her as villain.

Follow at a distance. If the party is suspicious but cautious, they might trail the cart. In this case, they witness the ambush: a dozen ragged figures emerging from treeline, farm tools repurposed as weapons, coordinated and quick. The militia are overwhelmed without anyone dying. Maren is cut free, shares a brief word with her rescuers, and disappears. The party now knows the "malcontents" are organized, capable, and disciplined enough to take prisoners rather than corpses.

docs.title: Talking to Maren
docs.text:
If the party gets a chance to speak with Maren (whether by freeing her, intercepting the ambush, or tracking her down afterward), she is wary but not hostile. She has no reason to trust strangers, but she also has nothing to hide.

She'll explain the situation plainly: Lord Thorne enclosed the commons three years ago. Families who'd worked that land for generations were told to pay new rents or leave. Those who couldn't pay—most of them—lost everything. Her husband didn't survive the first winter. Now two dozen families live in shanties at the edge of what used to be their home, and the lord sends militia to make sure they don't get any ideas about taking it back.

"We tried asking nicely," she says. "We tried the courts. We tried everything that's supposed to work. None of it did. So now we try other things."

If asked about curses, magic, hags, or anything supernatural, Maren looks at them like they've lost their minds. "I'm a farmer's widow, not a witch. If I could curse lords, don't you think I'd have done it by now?" She has no knowledge of anything magical happening at the estate. She has no interest in it either. Her fight is about land, not sorcery.

The Swann Situation: If the party asks about her people or the resistance, Maren's expression darkens. She'll admit that her leadership is faltering. Half the Malcontents have thrown in with Lord Duncan Swann, a neighboring noble who's made promises about protecting them if they support his claims against Thorne. "They think he's different. They think a new lord will be better than the old one. I've tried to tell them—Swann is worse. His own tenants live like dogs. But my people are tired, and scared, and he's telling them what they want to hear. I don't have anything to offer except more fighting with no end in sight."

This is important information, but players may not recognize its significance yet. They may even suspect Swann is behind the curse. Let them hold that thought. It will be corrected soon.

docs.title: Initial Clues
docs.text:
The Manor: Thorne's study contains campaign journals. Several pages have been torn out—specifically entries from his final weeks in dreamstrider territory. Later entries show methodical enclosure strategies applied to local peasants. A locked box holds dried coast leaf he claims he stopped using years ago. An insight check should have players ask themselves, "why is he keeping something he stopped using years ago in a locked box?" Aldric cannot explain why.

The Staff: Servants describe collective dreams: standing in circles, salt water and black sand, a presence watching. One maid notices Lady Isra never seems surprised by these descriptions.

The Guards: Confirm supernatural irresistible sleep, midnight to dawn. One older guard, Torm, remembers coast leaf and strange dreams from back when he served at the frontier as a young man, but he never made it deeper into the territories.

Medical Examination: Any healer confirms impossible wounds. Perfect cauterization, no scarring, no pain. Surgical deletion rather than traumatic injury.

Lord Thorne: Becomes uncomfortable but not evasive when questioned about colonial service. Genuinely disturbed by his inability to recall why he left. If asked about enclosures, he shows no awareness they mirror his colonial work.

If the party mentions Lord Swann in connection with the Malcontents, Thorne's reaction is illuminating. He scoffs openly: "Swann? Duncan Swann? He's one of the worst noblemen in the region, and one of those who mocked me most loudly for being 'too gentle with the smallfolk.' If those farmers think he'll treat them better, they're fools." This is both self-serving and true. Thorne genuinely cannot see that "better than Swann" is not the same as "good," but his assessment of Swann's character is accurate. More importantly, this moment cracks open Thorne's self-image: he positions himself as moderate, reasonable, caught between ungrateful peasants and brutal peers. He has no framework for understanding that he and Swann are variations on a theme rather than opposites.

Lady Isra: Maintains careful performance. Answers factually but volunteers nothing. Perceptive characters notice: she never suggests solutions, never asks about cures. Her concern is technically performed but emotionally absent.

If asked about coast leaf, her contempt flashes through: "That's cousin to our sacred kelp. You people take everything and corrupt it. The plant unprepared is a doorway you can't control." She might explain the dreamstriders knew the wild kelp's dangers—their ancestors developed ritual techniques specifically to make navigation safe. The crude smoking method is precisely what their elders warned against.

If asked about her marriage, her mask slips differently—not contempt but something colder. "He believes he saved me. He believes I should be grateful." She will not elaborate unless the party has earned significant trust.

In Isra's chambers is dried kelp in wax-sealed containers, a brazier for controlled burning, notes in dreamstrider language describing Dream navigation.

The Village: The displaced families live in makeshift shelters near former common lands—a shantytown of salvaged timber and desperation. Armed militia patrol the perimeter, and the tension is immediate: these are people under siege, not simply poor. Signs of recent confrontation mark the camp: a burned structure (the cause is disputed—see below), fresh graves, faces that track the party with exhausted wariness.

Maren speaks for the camp, but her authority is visibly contested. The Malcontents have fractured. Those who remain with Maren are the ones who either trust her judgment or have nowhere else to go. The others—roughly half the original group—left weeks ago to seek Lord Swann's protection.

The Swann Defectors' Fate: If the party asks about the defectors, Maren's expression goes flat. "They went to Swann. He heard them out. Then he had his men beat them bloody and dump them at the crossroads. Said he doesn't harbor 'malcontents' and if they wanted his help they should have thought of that before making trouble for their betters." Some of the beaten families crawled back to Maren's camp. Others scattered. A few are simply gone—whether dead, fled, or in Swann's dungeons, no one knows.

This information is crucial for defusing the "Swann is behind it" theory that players may be nurturing. Swann is a brutal opportunist, not a mastermind. He was happy to dangle hope in front of desperate people when it cost him nothing, and equally happy to crush them when they actually showed up asking for help. He's not connected to the curse. He's just another lord doing what lords do.

The Burned Barn: The party may ask about the burned storage barn mentioned in their briefing. Maren doesn't deny that it happened, but the details remain contested even within her own camp. Some say it was a deliberate strike against Thorne's resources. Some say it was an accident during a supply raid that went wrong. Some whisper that it was the Swann defectors, trying to force a crisis that would make Swann's "protection" seem necessary. Maren herself won't say who did it or why. What she will say: "A barn full of grain burned. Grain grown on land that was ours. By hands that used to be ours. I won't weep for Lord Thorne's ledgers."

GM Note: Keep the barn burning ambiguous. The adventure doesn't need to resolve this question, and leaving it open preserves the moral complexity of the resistance. What matters is that the players understand Maren's people are not unified, not pure, and not in control of everything done in their name.

Mosley: Mosley positions himself as helpful but indispensable. He knows how Thorne thinks, how colonial campaigns were run, how coast leaf “kept men functional.” He tries to steer the investigation toward Maren’s people, toward curses, anything that keeps attention off the past and buys Moghara time to carry out her procedure on Aldric Thorne. He will openly defend Aldric’s enclosures as “necessary discipline,” the same language he once used for pacification.

If the party presses him about his service with Thorne, his story stays vague until they corner him. Then he admits he still smokes coast leaf, that it gives him “clarity,” and that Aldric once took the same comfort. If later on confronted with the kelp’s dream-effects or Moghara’s influence, Mosley grows cold and quietly dangerous: he will threaten, sabotage, or even attempt murder rather than let the truth surface.

If the party gets too close to uncomfortable truths, steering them toward the stash becomes a disposal method for Mosley: "You want answers? Aldric used to smoke this and see things. Maybe it'll show you what you need." He's feeding them to his mistress, Moghara.

*Aldric Hardened: If the party accepts Mosley’s framing that violence is tragic but required, that Maren’s people are the real problem, that Aldric’s suffering proves he is being unfairly persecuted, Aldric retreats into the old colonial logic. Mosley becomes his living reminder to stop questioning his past.*

*Aldric Humbled: If Mosley is exposed, forced to admit his bargain, his addiction to coast leaf, his willingness to let Aldric be carved apart rather than lose the old order, Aldric is confronted with his own reflection. This is what he was. This is what he almost still is. The shame is inescapable.*

Petra: Petra watches everything. She cleans Isra’s rooms, smells the kelp smoke, constantly watches her for micro-expressions. She will eagerly whisper to the party that Lady Isra is a witch who brought this curse with her. Her bigoted hatred is obvious. If the party indulges her, she will give them access: keys, rumors, half-overheard conversations. She will happily sneak them into Isra’s chambers. But she will also sabotage any attempt at trust, spreading poison that makes cooperation with Isra almost impossible.

If the party challenges Petra’s racism, separates what she has seen from what she assumes, she becomes less useful but more honest. She still points them toward the kelp, the brazier, the midnight rituals, but without trying to turn it into a story of foreign corruption.

*Isra Hardened: If Petra is encouraged, Isra becomes more isolated, convinced no one sees her as anything but a threat. She retreats into bitterness and revenge.*

*Isra Humbled: If Petra is confronted and contained, Isra feels less isolated. That fragile crack makes solidarity with the party and with Maren possible.*

The Coast Leaf Connection: If the party cross-references Thorne's journal with his coast leaf use, the pattern emerges: every mention of smoking is followed within days by strategic insights about the dreamstrider threat. His handwriting changes subtly in these entries—more angular, unusual spacing. Moghara was guiding his hand.

docs.title: The First Descent
docs.text: If the party smokes the extra potent Coast Leaf from Aldric's stash, they enter the Dreamspace without proper ritual and fall into a warped twilight space, Moghara’s hunting fringe. Gravity wavers. Distances loop. Sounds distort as if underwater.

docs.title: The Children
docs.text: Before the party can orient themselves, something moves in the geometric dark. 1-4 (number depends on party strength) of Moghara's offspring, bear-sized spiders with limited spellcasting ability, clock the party as interference. This is a tough encounter, especially as the characters are not at full capacity. When the party finally wins—and they should have to work for this— 20-50 more emerge from the web-structure. Way too many to deal with.

docs.title: Taalen
docs.text:
Then, a figure steps forward from the web, half covered in spiderweb forming geometric patterns over his body, threads running and pulsing just under his skin like visible veins. He raises a translucent hand and speaks a word in Deep Speech. The children withdraw into the darkness.

"They're bound to their mother and to the contract." Taalen's voice is exhausted. "The contract includes me. For now, I'm something like a steward. They'll obey if I don't ask too much."If the party explains they've been hired to save Thorne, he becomes upset. "You're here to save him? The man whose folly and cruelty caused all this?" This may shut down further conversation and make future attempts to gain his trust harder. Otherwise, he speaks in fragments, clearly afraid, clearly constrained: "You shouldn't be here. She will notice. Go back. Don't come back without proper preparation. Find the woman—the one who still dreams with us." Then he's gone in an instant, and they are left alone to deal with the Dream Queen. Moghara manifests as part of the landscape, cycling through forms, coming and going:

A Little Girl: Eight years old, too many joints in her fingers. "You came here on purpose. Why? He's mine. The contract says so."

A Ancient Oak: Gnarled tree growing webs instead of leaves. "The fear of your ancestors has been forgotten. Good. Now offer me your deal, your innermost wishes."

A Black Dog: Wolf-sized, eight eyes. "You smell of determination. Do you think you can fight me? You don't even know where you are."

She makes it clear everything has a price, but is hazy on the specifics. Any character who actively agrees to a bargain (needs to be clearly expressed by the player) wakes immediately in their body. For the rest of the adventure, they suffer severe disadvantage in any confrontation with Moghara or her agents. They have already been partially claimed. But their wish will actually be met, within reason. On a very high Perception check, another party member may notice something wrong: a single, impossibly fine thread of spider silk disappearing into the bargainer’s ear. If they try to pull it, it never ends. The front of the thread vanishes as it is drawn, leaving no coil behind. It cannot be removed by force. It will remain there until the character’s contract is destroyed, or until Moghara comes to collect.

This episode establishes at the very least that the Dream is inhabited by a predatory spirit, teaches the players that deals are the currency here, and may plant the idea that Aldric’s suffering is not necessarily a curse, but a collection. They may also realize Mosley deliberately sent them into the hunting ground, leading them to understand viscerally how Moghara operates. She doesn't need to be present. She has people. The may also understand that Isra knows more about it than she lets on.

docs.title: Gaining the Kelp
docs.text:
Only by using real sacred kelp can they enter the dreamscape without being severely disadvantaged. Isra will not volunteer the kelp. She wants Thorne dead. Convincing her requires offering her something she values more than revenge.

The party must help her see that Moghara isn't punishing Thorne for justice—she's demonstrating control. But understanding this intellectually isn't enough. Isra has spent fifteen years surviving through carefully maintained bitterness. She needs to believe there's an alternative to simply trading masters.

If the party brings Isra and Maren together—or if clever roleplay creates that connection—something important can happen. Maren can articulate what Isra feels but hasn't framed: that loyalty to Moghara isn't a road to a future, it's just a different slavery. Appeasement can never buy the dreamstriders a future. The spider and the lord operate the same way, just with different tools. This can humble Isra considerably, giving her a language for what she's felt but couldn't articulate. This makes her more willing to help the party out, provided they make clear they're actually working against Moghara, and not just for her husband.

Isra might provide the kelp while shaking with complicated emotion—rage at saving Thorne, fear of Moghara, fragile hope that this time might be different. Or she might refuse. Revenge might still win. The party would then need another path into the Dream, or must accept that Thorne dies and turn attention to protecting Isra and her people from consequences.

docs.title: The Dream Confrontation
docs.text: Eventually, the players realize the only way to save Aldric Thorne is to re-enter the Dreamspace and confront Moghara again.

docs.title: Entering the Dream
docs.text:
If Isra provides kelp, she explains preparation with clinical detachment. Otherwise they must figure it out by translating the manuscript in her room, or succeeding on very hard ability checks. The kelp burns in a controlled brazier. Participants inhale and maintain rhythmic breathing. Transition takes roughly ten minutes, and she takes them directly to the Deep Dream.

She warns them: "The Dream is real, with its own geography and inhabitants. You're walking into deep waters with no map. This is Moghara's domain. You're prey entering predator territory." If they were to venture blindly into the Deep Dream to seek Moghara out in her own domain, they would simly perish, achieving nothing. Therefore, they can only enter at midnight, following the pathway Moghara creates for the nightly ritual, knowing exactly where she is.

This also means: A lot of other people are there, as witnesses. These people can be activated in the final confrontation.

If they have Humbled Isra at this point, she will offer to join them in the encounter. If she is hardened, she will still join, but after the players, entering the encounter as a spectator on a later turn count.

docs.title: The Deep Dream
docs.text:
A vast beach of black sand under starless sky. Dark ocean smelling of salt and kelp. Behind them, geometric patterns hang in the air—Moghara's webs in their true form, pulsing with bioluminescence. Tiny spiders scuttle along them carrying thought-fragments.

Underwater, vast architecture: dreamstrider cultural memory. Closer, trapped in webs extending into the water: humanoid figures—the dreamstriders forced to witness. Lord Thorne is here, paralyzed, awaiting collection. The guards stand in their circle, not quite conscious.

docs.title: Moghara
docs.text:
In her true form: vast spider, her rear body spanning sea to sky, countless legs forming geometric patterns across the horizon, web extending through the expanses of the Deep Dream. Her front is disproportionately smaller, but still huge. This means her body covers one full side of the battlefield in a chitinous void criss-crossed by labyrinthine webs, and her front part moves slowly, mostly acting through Lair Actions and Spells. She's powerful, but her reach is limited to her hunting grounds. She can only affect the waking world through specific connections, such as an anchor, or a contract.

Somewhere attached to Moghara is Thorne's contract—a living thing pulsing with violated terms. Nearby, larger and more complex, is the Dreamstrider Contract—the original bargain that bound her to their people and them to her.

docs.title: Moghara as Patron
docs.text: Moghara could make for a Warlock patron (Great Old One) if any of your players wants to take a level in Warlock.

docs.title: Resolution
docs.text:
Moghara cannot be defeated through violence. She is native to the Deep Dream. Fighting her there is fighting the ocean by hitting water. But she can be negotiated with, even misled. Her power is immense, but outside her domain it can only be accessed through contracts. Therefore she's always interested in trades.

The midnight ritual functions as a contested space with three levers the party must pull:

  • Moghara's attention (Charisma checks, Stealth checks, Other)
  • The children's position (Combat checks, Spells, Battlefield control)
  • The Dreamstriders' ability to communicate (Charisma checks, plot points, standing with NPC's)

Moghara is vast and powerful, but not omniscient. Her attention is a resource that can be split, occupied, or misdirected. The children are enforcers who respond to perceived threats (but they are easier now that the party is at full strength). The Dreamstriders are present, but bound and monitored. Each front represents a different tactical challenge, and success on one front opens possibilities on the others.

The confrontation should feel like juggling—every action creates vulnerability elsewhere. Track three resources: Moghara's attention (focused, split, or distracted), children positioning (patrolling, engaged, or suppressed), and Dreamstrider awareness (isolated, receiving information, or deliberating). Each player action affects one or more of these. Let players coordinate so that one character's sacrifice creates another character's opportunity.

When the party enters the Deep Dream during the ritual, they find a situation already in progress: Thorne paralyzed for collection, the Dreamstriders suspended in webs as compelled witnesses, the children patrolling, and Moghara preparing her performance. The question is not "can you stop Moghara" but "what can you accomplish before she stops you."

docs.title: Scenario Pathways
docs.text:
The Rescue Run The party's minimal goal is extracting Lord Thorne alive. This requires destroying his personal contract and escaping before Moghara can retaliate. Tactical sequence: Draw Moghara's attention (conversation, provocation), suppress or evade the children (combat, stealth, Taalen's limited authority), locate and destroy the contract (physical action), flee. This is achievable without touching the Dreamstrider situation at all. It saves one man, leaves everything else unchanged, and represents the party choosing limited good over risky better. Aftermath: Aldric lives, Dreamstriders remain bound, Moghara continues her patient extraction, nothing fundamental changes. More focus on whether Isra and Aldric are Hardened or Humbled.

The Information Play The party attempts to change the game by revealing Moghara's manipulation. This requires extended engagement: they need to occupy Moghara, suppress the children, reach the Dreamstriders, communicate complex information, and protect the resulting deliberation. The tactical sequence is staged: opening engagement splits attention, combat creates windows, communication happens in fragments across multiple approaches, eventual Dreamstrider consensus triggers Taalen's authority. This is slower and more dangerous than the rescue run, but opens renegotiation as a possibility.

Structure this as a skill challenge with multiple stages: early failure means incomplete information transfer. The party will have to fall back on simply saving Aldric. Later failure means the Dreamstriders do not necessarily believe the party. New attempts can be made, but are risky as the encounter drags on. The aftermath depends on what information reached the Dreamstriders and whether they achieved consensus. If they did, and the party survives the time deliberating, Taalen invokes deliberation clauses and enter formal dispute. The Dream becomes a courtroom.
